finding: The SNP rs3184504 was identified as an outlier in MR-PRESSO but did not distort the estimates related to the inverse association between genetically determined birth weight and LADA. When excluded from the instrumental variables, the outlier-corrected odds ratio (OR) was 1.83 (95% CI: 1.29-2.59), further supporting the finding of an inverse association between birth weight and LADA.
title: Birth weight, BMI in adulthood and latent autoimmune diabetes in adults: A Mendelian randomization study

finding: The SNP rs11066188 was detected as an outlier by MR-PRESSO but did not distort the outlier-corrected estimate related to the association of adult BMI and LADA. The OR obtained with the remaining instrumental variables was consistent with the results from IVW, demonstrating a positive association of adult BMI with LADA.
title: Birth weight, BMI in adulthood and latent autoimmune diabetes in adults: A Mendelian randomization study

finding: Part of the <italic>Late Rise</italic> cluster, rs7132908 was significantly associated with early childhood BMI and continued to show effects into adulthood.
title: Characterization of the genetic architecture of BMI in infancy and early childhood reveals age-specific effects and implicates pathways involved in Mendelian obesity

finding: The variant rs1626329 was located in the P2RX7 locus, identified as a lead variant for chronic alanine aminotransferase elevation (cALT) across diverse ancestries, suggesting its role in metabolic liver disease.
title: A trans-ancestry genome-wide association study of unexplained chronic ALT elevation as a proxy for nonalcoholic fatty liver disease with histological and radiological validation

finding: The lead peak variant for European-American analysis was rs1169292, found in the HNF1A gene, which is also in strong linkage disequilibrium with the coding variant rs1169288 (Ile27Leu), pointing to its involvement in conditions related to liver metabolism.
title: A trans-ancestry genome-wide association study of unexplained chronic ALT elevation as a proxy for nonalcoholic fatty liver disease with histological and radiological validation

finding: This coding variant, Ala348Thr in P2RX7, was noted for being in strong linkage disequilibrium with the lead SNP rs1626329, reinforcing its candidate gene status for metabolic liver diseases linked to cALT.
title: A trans-ancestry genome-wide association study of unexplained chronic ALT elevation as a proxy for nonalcoholic fatty liver disease with histological and radiological validation

finding: rs1169288 represented a distinct coding variant (Ile27Leu) in the HNF1A gene, identified among the significant SNPs associated with cALT and liver disease pathways.
title: A trans-ancestry genome-wide association study of unexplained chronic ALT elevation as a proxy for nonalcoholic fatty liver disease with histological and radiological validation

finding: The low-frequency missense variant rs113791087 in the PTPRB gene was identified as significantly associated with an increased risk of central serous chorioretinopathy (CSC), with an odds ratio (OR) of 2.85 (P=4.5x10^-9). The association was consistent across multiple studies and confirmed in a meta-analysis featuring 2,452 CSC patients and 865,767 controls, yielding an OR of 3.06 (P=7.4x10^-15). This SNP was also linked to retinal abnormalities and varicose veins, with associations showing an OR of 1.31 (P=2.3x10^-11) for varicose veins, highlighting its role in both ocular and systemic vascular diseases.
title: Rare genetic variation in VE-PTP is associated with central serous chorioretinopathy, venous dysfunction and glaucoma

finding: Functioning as a proxy, this SNP also exhibited a strong association with usual walking pace, contributing to the findings regarding migraine risk reduction.
title: Potential Causal Relationship between Faster Walking Pace and Reduced Migraine Risk: A Mendelian Randomization Study

finding: The SNP rs10774671 was associated with splice variation in the gene OAS1, which was determined to be causal for COVID-19 severity.
title: Whole Genome DNA and RNA Sequencing of Whole Blood Elucidates the Genetic Architecture of Gene Expression Underlying a Wide Range of Diseases

finding: The variant rs2120513666, which corresponds to the mutation NM 003482:exon32:c.8047-2A>G, was identified as a pathogenic splicing variant in the gene KMT2D. This variant disrupted the acceptor site of exon 33 and was absent in the germline but present in the tumor tissue with an allelic ratio of 50%, indicating a high tumor purity. It was considered a potential driver for a mixed somato-lactotroph tumor.
title: Whole Genome Sequencing and single-cell transcriptomics identify KMT2D as a potential new driver for pituitary adenomas

finding: The SNP rs11172113 was identified as the most strongly associated with pain susceptibility in the genome-wide analysis. The alternate allele was linked to an increased risk for pain and previously associated with decreased expression of LRP1 and increased intron-excision splicing of STAT6. The Mendelian randomization analysis suggested that the increased pain was mediated by decreased pulmonary function, indicating that this locus may impact pain susceptibility by modulating inflammatory processes.
title: GWAS meta-analysis reveals dual neuronal and immunological etiology for pain susceptibility

finding: This SNP was identified as influencing glutamine's causal effect on Alzheimer's disease, showing a nominally significant negative effect (OR = 0.87) on the disease. It was also associated with the ratio of histidine-to-glutamine, marking it as a positive original finding in the context of Alzheimer's disease.
title: Evaluating metabolome-wide causal effects on risk for psychiatric and neurodegenerative disorders

finding: The variant rs14024 in the KRT1 gene was found to be significantly associated with dermatophytosis (p = 3.95×10^-15, beta = -0.030), highlighting its potential role in keratinization processes linked to the infection.
title: The genetic basis of dermatophytosis skin infection susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs28577594 was implicated in SCZ risk through its association with the isoform ENST00000537270 of KMT5A, showing a strong isoQTL signal with a significant negative effect on the transcript expression, while the variant demonstrated a protective effect against SCZ.
title: Isoform-level transcriptome-wide association uncovers extensive novel genetic risk mechanisms for neuropsychiatric disorders in the human brain

finding: The SNP rs11170516 was identified to be associated with moderate-severe hypospadias, as reported by Chen et al. This finding contributed to understanding the genetic basis of hypospadias, particularly the role of polymorphisms in the etiology of the condition.
title: Whole-exome Sequencing Study of Hypospadias

finding: The <italic>VDR</italic><sup>rs7975232</sup> CC genotype was found to be independently associated with an asymptomatic phenotype in patients with Cerebral Cavernous Malformations (CCM). Furthermore, individuals carrying the CC genotype exhibited decreased levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines such as IL-27 and IL-23, suggesting a potential protective role of this genotype in the disease.
title: Genetic Markers and Predictive Factors Influencing the Aggressive Behavior of Cerebral Cavernous Malformation

finding: The <italic>VDR</italic><sup>rs731236</sup> AA genotype correlated with a delayed onset of symptoms in CCM patients (HR 0.52, p = 0.020), indicating that those with this genotype tended to present their symptoms later in life.
title: Genetic Markers and Predictive Factors Influencing the Aggressive Behavior of Cerebral Cavernous Malformation

finding: The <italic>VDR</italic><sup>rs11568820</sup> CC genotype was associated with an earlier onset of symptoms in the CCM cohort (HR 1.58, p = 0.016), suggesting its influence on the timing of disease manifestation.
title: Genetic Markers and Predictive Factors Influencing the Aggressive Behavior of Cerebral Cavernous Malformation

finding: The SNP LRRK2 rs76904798 was identified as having predictive associations, particularly concerning neurological assessments in Parkinson's disease.
title: The multi-modality neuroimaging analysis identified an essential genetic variant associated with Parkinson’s disease

finding: The rs34637584 SNP located in the LRRK2 locus (p.G2019S) was associated with a significantly reduced risk for PD+RBD, displaying an odds ratio of 0.41 and a p-value of 1.04E-5, suggesting a protective role in the development of PD+RBD.
title: Genome-wide association study of REM sleep behavior disorder in Parkinson’s disease

finding: The SNP rs17442721 in the noncoding RNA LINC02555 was identified as protective against developing dementia, with an odds ratio of 0.43 (95% CI = 0.32 - 0.57, P = 1.44e-08). This SNP tagged the LRRK2 G2019S variant and was shown to lose significance when conditioned on the G2019S variant.
title: Investigation of the genetic aetiology of Lewy body diseases with and without dementia

finding: The SNP rs10437796 near the SYT10 gene had a nominal protective association against PD death (HR=0.71, p=0.05) and increased non-PD deaths (HR=1.50, p=1.8×10^-4).
title: Genome-wide determinants of mortality and clinical progression in Parkinson’s disease

finding: The rs653178 SNP exhibited the strongest signal in association with energy (P=1.3x10^-106) and run length non-uniformity (P=9.2x10^-72). This SNP is significant for its role in the splenic feature genetic overlap while being associated with variations in systolic and diastolic blood pressure.
title: Deep learning-derived splenic radiomics, genomics, and coronary artery disease

finding: SNP rs141843711 located on chromosome 12 was found to be significantly associated with AN. Its overlap with BMI points to shared genetic factors that might contribute to these two phenotypes.
title: An Evolutionary Perspective on the Genetics of Anorexia Nervosa

finding: The missense variant rs5442 in the GNB3 gene was associated with retinal nerve fibre layer thickness and had relevance to the risk of degenerative disc disease, indicated by a beta of -0.11 and a p-value of 6.74×10^-23. This underscored the connection between genetic factors influencing eye morphology and other health risks.
title: A predictive atlas of disease onset from retinal fundus photographs

finding: The variant rs2135845768 in HNF1A was associated with altered expression of four plasma proteins, and was found to reduce levels of ACE2, which is critical for glycemia and beta-cell function.
title: Genetic regulation of the plasma proteome and its link to cardiometabolic disease in Greenlandic Inuit

finding: The study found that the FokI-FF genotype (rs2228570) was significantly more prevalent in T1D patients with an odds ratio of 1.66 (p < 0.03), indicating a susceptibility association with Type 1 diabetes. Additionally, the transition from F (C allele) to f (T allele) correlated with an increased risk due to altered VDR protein stability, suggesting a functional impact of this SNP on disease prevalence.
title: Association of Vitamin D deficiency and vitamin D receptor gene polymorphisms with type 1 diabetes risk: A South Indian familial study

finding: The BsmI-B allele (rs1544410) showed a significant association with T1D risk, with transmission disequilibrium test results indicating over-transmission of the B allele (p < 0.01). This suggested that individuals carrying this allele may have an increased likelihood of developing Type 1 diabetes.
title: Association of Vitamin D deficiency and vitamin D receptor gene polymorphisms with type 1 diabetes risk: A South Indian familial study

finding: The study observed over-transmission of the ApaI-A allele (rs7975232) from parents to T1D patients (T: U = 15/5; p < 0.006), indicating that this allele may contribute to risk in the development of Type 1 diabetes.
title: Association of Vitamin D deficiency and vitamin D receptor gene polymorphisms with type 1 diabetes risk: A South Indian familial study

finding: The OASL-P2RX7 locus (lead SNP rs2708101) disclosed a novel association with estrone levels.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide association study in 34,394 Chinese women reveals the genetic architecture of plasma metabolites during pregnancy

finding: The SNP rs4767027, located in the OAS1 gene, was significantly associated with decreased likelihood of COVID-19 susceptibility and severity. This finding stemmed from a genetic study in individuals of European ancestry, confirming the relevance of the cis-protein quantitative trait loci (pQTL) in type I IFN-mediated immunity, which is crucial for providing initial protection against viral infections. Furthermore, in the context of aged COVID-19 patients, those presenting with severe cases exhibited reduced expression of type I IFN genes, highlighting the importance of OAS1 and associated pathways in the immune response against COVID-19.
title: Aging-related cell type-specific pathophysiologic immune responses that exacerbate disease severity in aged COVID-19 patients

finding: The SNP rs3184504 was associated with six proteins: CXCL9, CXCL10, CXCL11, CD5, CD244, and IL12B, indicating its relevance in a trans-pQTL hotspot.
title: Mapping pQTLs of circulating inflammatory proteins identifies drivers of immune-related disease risk and novel therapeutic targets

finding: This SNP was associated with LTA, indicating a potential role in multiple sclerosis pathogenesis by linking low LTBR levels to elevated LTA protein.
title: Mapping pQTLs of circulating inflammatory proteins identifies drivers of immune-related disease risk and novel therapeutic targets

finding: The SNP rs1800693 was confirmed to have an independent association with multiple sclerosis, functioning upstream of rs2364485.
title: Mapping pQTLs of circulating inflammatory proteins identifies drivers of immune-related disease risk and novel therapeutic targets

finding: SNP rs76169231 was jointly associated with systolic blood pressure, pulse pressure, and brainstem volumes, particularly involving the whole brainstem, midbrain, and pons. This locus was linked to the WASHC3 gene, which regulates endolysosomal membrane trafficking, necessitating further research into its role in hypertension.
title: Large-scale brainstem neuroimaging and genetic analyses provide new insights into the neuronal mechanisms of hypertension

finding: The SNP rs11111293 shared associations with systolic blood pressure, pulse pressure, and the whole brainstem, midbrain, and pons. It was mapped to the WASHC3 gene, influencing endolysosomal membrane trafficking, and further investigation into its contribution to hypertension was warranted.
title: Large-scale brainstem neuroimaging and genetic analyses provide new insights into the neuronal mechanisms of hypertension

finding: An intronic SNP in FRS2 was significantly associated with FEV1 in the UK Biobank and SpiroMeta, with a p-value of 1.2 × 10^-10. This finding provided additional evidence for the signal at this locus, which was missed by prior studies.
title: Powerful gene-based testing by integrating long-range chromatin interactions and knockoff genotypes

finding: The SNP rs10843036 was associated specifically with pregnancy zone protein (PZP) in females, indicating a significant finding related to female reproductive biology.
title: Similar and different: systematic investigation of proteogenomic variation between sexes and its relevance for human diseases

finding: The SNP rs1006737 was identified as correlated with alterations in cortical function during executive cognition and higher mRNA levels of CACNA1C, a gene linked to schizophrenia. This SNP was among the first GWAS hits, suggesting its significant role in the genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders.
title: Variant-risk-exon interplay impacts circadian rhythm and dopamine signaling pathway in severe psychiatric disorders

finding: The SNP rs4766578 at the 12q24.12 locus showed a remarkably consistent degree of pleiotropy across several trait pairs. It was located in the binding sequence of the transcription factor HNF4A, which is a crucial regulatory element of the ALDH2 gene, linked to significant health outcomes such as blood pressure and cardiovascular and autoimmune diseases.
title: Genetic analyses identify shared genetic components related to autoimmune and cardiovascular diseases

finding: The SNP rs10744777 within the 12q24.11-12 locus acted as an eQTL for ALDH2 in monocytes, linking it to ischemia-reperfusion injury mitigation in serious cardiovascular events, showcasing its protective role in cardiovascular diseases.
title: Genetic analyses identify shared genetic components related to autoimmune and cardiovascular diseases

finding: The SNP rs3184504 was found to have significant pleiotropic effects associated with both immunological disorders and cardiovascular diseases. The A risk allele was linked to increased activation of the NOD2 recognition pathway, contributing to a pro-inflammatory response and potential cardiac injury.
title: Genetic analyses identify shared genetic components related to autoimmune and cardiovascular diseases

finding: The rs4149032 SNP was confirmed as a significant covariate for rifampicin pharmacokinetics, with patients harboring this variant achieving lower plasma exposure to the drug compared to wildtype individuals. Virtual simulations indicated that a standard dose of 750 mg was optimal for patients with this variant to achieve the target AUC of 54.2 µg·h/mL.
title: AI coupled to pharmacometric modelling to tailor malaria and tuberculosis treatment in Africa

finding: The SNP rs1169299 at the HNF1A locus was identified as having significant ancestry-correlated heterogeneity, particularly with evidence indicating it was negatively associated with the AFR-EAS axis and positively associated with the AFR-EUR axis. With an odds ratio (OR) of 1.02 for African ancestry, it presented an allelic effect that was intermediate between the effects observed for East Asian (OR=0.95) and European (OR=1.05) ancestries.
title: Multi-ancestry genome-wide study in >2.5 million individuals reveals heterogeneity in mechanistic pathways of type 2 diabetes and complications

finding: A significant eQTL for ALDH2 in aorta, this SNP associated with males, further exhibiting its biological role in aortic traits.
title: GENOME-WIDE ASSOCIATIONS OF AORTIC DISTENSIBILITY SUGGEST CAUSAL RELATIONSHIPS WITH AORTIC ANEURYSMS AND BRAIN WHITE MATTER HYPERINTENSITIES

finding: This SNP was associated with FEV1 (P=4.20×10^-8, β=0.0219) and was noted for its previous associations with height, alcohol use disorder, high-density lipoprotein, and type 2 diabetes.
title: Multi-trait and multi-ancestry genetic analysis of comorbid lung diseases and traits improves genetic discovery and polygenic risk prediction

finding: The SNP rs11055602 was characterized as a GR-response meQTL located on chromosome 12. It demonstrated effects both prior to and following dexamethasone treatment, where individuals with the major genotype showed a notable decrease in methylation levels, while those with the minor allele genotype exhibited an increase, with an FDR of 5.1x10^-30. This highlighted its role in modulating gene expression linked to glucocorticoid response.
title: Multi-omics analysis of the molecular response to glucocorticoids - insights into shared genetic risk from psychiatric to medical disorders

finding: The study reported that rs77395454, a variant in the intronic region of CORO1C on chromosome 12, met genome-wide significance for the penetrance model in LRRK2 mutation carriers, suggesting it modifies the penetrance of LRRK2 mutations.
title: Genome-wide association studies of LRRK2 modifiers of Parkinson’s disease

finding: The variant rs10774740 was associated with posterior urethral valves (PUV) and demonstrated a significant P-value of 7.81×10⁻¹² and an odds ratio of 0.40, indicating a protective effect.
title: Whole-genome sequencing reveals contribution of rare and common variation to structural kidney and urinary tract malformations

finding: With its nominal BMI association leading to its exclusion in certain analyses, this SNP was still relevant in the causative relationship between pancreas fat and PDAC.
title: Genetic Evidence Causally Linking Pancreas Fat to Pancreatic Cancer: A Mendelian Randomization Study

finding: The protective G allele of OAS1 rs10774671 was found significantly associated with protection against severe COVID-19 in the Moroccan population. It represented a prevalence of 40.4%, which was close to that of Europeans (35.2%). This allele was present on both the Neanderthal GGG and African GAC haplotypes, both of which were significantly associated with reduced severity of COVID-19. The Neanderthal haplotype was found predominantly in Berbers, indigenous to North Africa.
title: Study of the protective OAS1 rs10774671-G allele against severe COVID-19 in Moroccans suggests a North African origin for Neanderthals

finding: The SNP rs4149056, associated with steroid and bile acid metabolism, represented significant associations with the odds of missingness of five metabolites, including estrone metabolites and unknown metabolite X-12456. These findings suggested its involvement in bile acid and cholesterol interaction, aligning with existing literature on its role in statin-induced myopathy.
title: Genome-wide Association Studies of Missing Metabolite Measures: Results From Two Population-based Studies

finding: Found at 12p12.1, rs11836164, which is in proximity to SSPN, was also significantly associated with V and had established links to DA, reinforcing the connections between mammographic texture and breast morphology.
title: A genome-wide association study of mammographic texture variation

finding: The SNP rs148024771 near AC019209.2/MIR4302/RASSF8 was associated significantly with a p-value of 3.89×10^-8 in the context of Alzheimer’s disease.
This SNP was found to colocalize with serum phosphate levels, presenting a high PP4 value of 0.94 and a frequency of 15.4% in 1000 Genomes Africans.
title: A Southern African Map of Blood Regulatory Variation Enables GWAS Interpretation

finding: The rs10735079A variant of the OAS3 gene was found to be protective against certain symptoms of COVID-19, specifically muscle aches (OR 0.34, 95% CI 0.13-0.88, P = 0.0248) and sore throat (OR 0.17, 95% CI 0.05-0.55, P < 0.001). These associations suggested that this variant may decrease the risk of developing these symptoms in COVID-19 patients.
title: Association of IFNAR2 rs2236757 and OAS3 rs10735079 polymorphisms with susceptibility to COVID-19 infection and severity

finding: The SNP rs10849448, near LTBR, was noted for its role in the development of tertiary lymphoid structures in COPD, highlighting its significance in COPD pathogenesis.
title: Leveraging deep-learning on raw spirograms to improve genetic understanding and risk scoring of COPD despite noisy labels

finding: The SNP rs2277339 was identified as an exonic missense variant in the PRIM1 gene, showing a significant association with female genital tract (FGT) polyps (P = 7.57 x 10<sup>-10</sup>). This gene may be involved in cellular proliferation, and its expression was found to be influenced by estrogen, suggesting potential mechanisms behind polyp development.
title: Large-scale genome-wide association study to determine the genetic underpinnings of female genital tract polyps

finding: The rs9668337 SNP was nominally significant in the association with FGT polyps, and it is linked with various reproductive malignancies, reflecting its possible role in clinical outcomes.
title: Large-scale genome-wide association study to determine the genetic underpinnings of female genital tract polyps

finding: This SNP was associated with endometrial cancer, reflecting its potential significance in FGT polyp development.
title: Large-scale genome-wide association study to determine the genetic underpinnings of female genital tract polyps

finding: The intergenic variant rs142145593 was found near MED13L and TBX3 on 12q24.21, with associations related to lung cancer and asthma risk.
title: Trans-ethnic genome-wide meta-analysis of 35,732 cases and 34,424 controls identifies novel genomic cross-ancestry loci contributing to lung cancer susceptibility

finding: This SNP linked to the WNK1 gene was discovered to be associated with squamous cell carcinoma risk.
title: Trans-ethnic genome-wide meta-analysis of 35,732 cases and 34,424 controls identifies novel genomic cross-ancestry loci contributing to lung cancer susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs28577594 was located at the locus for the isoform ENST00000537270 of the gene KMT5A, associated with schizophrenia risk. The lead isoQTL signal was strong with a negative effect on transcript-isoform expression, corresponding to a protective effect against SCZ.
title: Isoform-level transcriptome-wide association uncovers extensive novel genetic risk mechanisms for neuropsychiatric disorders in the human brain

finding: The SNP rs753877638 is a start-loss variant in <italic>ACAD10</italic> that had significant associations with both IOP (P = 1.30 × 10<sup>−10</sup>, beta = 8.41) and glaucoma (P = 3.68 × 10<sup>−4</sup>) in the UK Biobank.
title: Whole-exome sequencing study identifies novel rare variants and genes associated with intraocular pressure and glaucoma

finding: The rs5030654 variant in PAH, associated with phenylketonuria, was identified as overrepresented in the Russian population, emphasizing its clinical significance.
title: Expanding the Russian allele frequency reference via cross-laboratory data integration: insights from 6,096 exome samples

finding: The SNP rs281865192, classified as a deep intronic founder variant in the gene CEP290, involved Sanger sequencing to confirm its likely pathogenic status. This variant was connected to hereditary tubulointerstitial kidney diseases, highlighting its biological relevance in the context of chronic kidney disease (CKD).
title: Prevalence of hereditary tubulointerstitial kidney diseases in the German Chronic Kidney Disease study

finding: The variant rs10774671 was associated with the OAS1 gene and identified as a likely causal variant for susceptibility to COVID-19 through its influence on RNA degradation pathways.
title: Insights into genetic factors contributing to variability in SARS-CoV-2 susceptibility and COVID-19 disease severity

finding: This SNP was associated with both the rapid progression subtype (Subtype III) and the mild progression subtype (Subtype I), suggesting it might play a role in varied progression patterns of PD.
title: Integrative analyses of multimodal clinical, neuroimaging, genetic, and transcriptomic data identify subtypes and potential treatments for heterogeneous Parkinson’s disease progression

finding: This SNP was associated with the mild progression subtype (Subtype I), suggesting it impacts clinical features of PD with less severity.
title: Integrative analyses of multimodal clinical, neuroimaging, genetic, and transcriptomic data identify subtypes and potential treatments for heterogeneous Parkinson’s disease progression

finding: The SNP rs2657879 predicted a protective causal effect of higher circulating glutamine levels on the development of NAFLD based on MR conservative analysis.
title: Causal relationships between genetically predicted circulating levels of amino acids and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease risk: a Mendelian randomisation study

finding: SNP rs11614913 in the MIR196 gene was associated with CHD. It showed significant association through the co-dominant model [χ2 = 16.24; P = 0.0003]. In the dominant model, the odds ratio was 1.918 (1.210-3.042; P = 0.0075), and in the recessive model, it demonstrated an odds ratio of 0.2754 (0.1369-0.5540; P = 0.0002), indicating a complex relationship with CHD.
title: The potential impact of microRNA-related functional polymorphisms in the pathogenesis of coronary heart disease

finding: This SNP was located near two genes (C1S and C1R) that encode proteins involved in complement cascade initiation, linking it to significant biological pathways.
title: The genetic and phenotypic correlates of neonatal Complement Component 3 and 4 protein concentrations with a focus on psychiatric and autoimmune disorders

finding: This SNP was identified as having a strong association with circulating sclerostin levels (β=-0.136, P=2.44×10^-73) and was associated with lower eBMD, providing evidence of its utility as a genetic instrument in examining causal effects of sclerostin on atherosclerosis-related diseases.
title: Lowering of circulating sclerostin may increase risk of atherosclerosis and its risk factors: evidence from a genome-wide association meta-analysis followed by Mendelian randomization

finding: In the context of alcohol consumption, rs56884502 was identified on chromosome 12q24.12 as having a significant association in the heterozygous genotype (A allele), relating to a decrease in daily alcohol intake among individuals carrying the heterozygous rs671 variant. This finding was novel and highlighted the protective effect of the A allele against alcohol consumption.
title: Genotype-stratified GWAS meta-analysis reveals novel loci associated with alcohol consumption

finding: Located at chromosome 12q24.12, rs7978737 was associated with drinking status, displaying a significant interaction with rs671. Its T allele was linked to increased alcohol consumption, indicating the variant's functional significance.
title: Genotype-stratified GWAS meta-analysis reveals novel loci associated with alcohol consumption

finding: SNP rs2657879 was identified as the genetic variant predicted to exert a causal effect on NAFLD risk related to glutamine levels, supporting the protective role of glutamine against the development of NAFLD.
title: Causal relationships between genetically predicted circulating levels of amino acids and NAFLD risk: a Mendelian randomisation study

finding: rs773121 was included in the haplotype consisting of the minor alleles found preferentially in women with PCOS and elevated androgen levels (p = 0.0583). It showed significant association with anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) levels (P<sub>emp</sub> = 0.00242), indicating potential functional consequences related to PA2G4 expression.
title: Loci on chromosome 12q13.2 encompassing ERBB3, PA2G4 and RAB5B are associated with polycystic ovary syndrome

finding: rs773123 was part of the haplotype with minor alleles, found more frequently in women with PCOS (p = 0.0583) and had a significant association with AMH levels (P<sub>emp</sub> = 0.00105). It is a missense SNP located in the ERBB3 gene, which suggests its involvement in androgen production related to PCOS.
title: Loci on chromosome 12q13.2 encompassing ERBB3, PA2G4 and RAB5B are associated with polycystic ovary syndrome

finding: rs812826 was associated with the same haplotype that approached significance concerning PCOS and was linked to AMH levels (P<sub>emp</sub> = 0.0009). This SNP is located in the promoter region of PA2G4, indicating a functional role in the context of androgen production in theca cells.
title: Loci on chromosome 12q13.2 encompassing ERBB3, PA2G4 and RAB5B are associated with polycystic ovary syndrome

finding: The variant rs4149056 was reported in the context of the SLCO1B1 gene and was found with a frequency of 12.5% among Indonesians, consistent with other reports in gnomAD, highlighting its role in statin metabolism and associated adverse events.
title: Validation of a multi-gene qPCR-based pharmacogenomics panel across major ethnic groups in Singapore and Indonesia

finding: The SNP rs3184504, which is located within the SH2B3 locus, demonstrated significant local genetic correlation with eosinophil count, lymphocyte count, T1D, and CAD. This correlation underscored that genetic variants at this locus were likely influential in the shared pathology of these diseases.
title: Genetic relations between leukocyte counts, type 1 diabetes, and coronary artery disease

finding: The SNP rs7137828, also found in the SH2B3 locus, was associated with the same significant local genetic correlations as rs3184504, highlighting its role in eosinophil and lymphocyte counts, as well as in the risk for T1D and CAD.
title: Genetic relations between leukocyte counts, type 1 diabetes, and coronary artery disease

finding: The SNP rs7132908 was identified as a causal variant associated with the childhood obesity chr12q13 locus, specifically implicated in the 3' UTR of the FAIM2 gene. This finding was part of a broader investigation into genetic factors influencing obesity, highlighting rs7132908's role in regulating gene expression related to weight disorders.
title: Shared and unique 3D genomic features of substance use disorders across multiple cell types

finding: In IDH-wildtype glioblastoma cases treated with TMZ, rs73191162-T near UNG was associated with a shorter survival time, with those carrying any T allele experiencing a median reduction of 3.2 months in survival compared to CC genotype carriers.
title: Functional germline variants in DNA damage repair pathways are associated with altered survival in adults with glioma treated with temozolomide

finding: Located at 12q21.2, this lead SNP exhibited suggestive significance (p=9.76×10^-7, OR=0.57) in the AVSD analysis and was noted for its proximity (84 kb) to NAV3, a neuronal regulator. It maintained suggestive significance in subsequent meta-analysis.
title: Genome-wide association studies of Down syndrome associated congenital heart defects

finding: Found at locus 12q13.12, it had p=2.57×10^-7 and OR=2.69 and contained genes active in heart development, with one SNP overlapping a known embryonic heart enhancer.
title: Genome-wide association studies of Down syndrome associated congenital heart defects

finding: This SNP also belonged to the 12q13.12 locus and showed potential eQTL evidence, supporting its involvement in heart development.
title: Genome-wide association studies of Down syndrome associated congenital heart defects

finding: The SNP rs597808 was identified as an expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) for genes in human brain tissues and was associated with multiple CMR traits, linking genetic influences on cardiovascular and neurological health.
title: Heart-brain connections: phenotypic and genetic insights from 40,000 cardiac and brain magnetic resonance images

finding: The SNP rs4148674 was linked with hippocampal sclerosis of aging and was identified as an eQTL in brain tissue, highlighting its relationship with neurological health.
title: Heart-brain connections: phenotypic and genetic insights from 40,000 cardiac and brain magnetic resonance images

finding: The SNP rs7310615 was associated with multiple genes in the brain and indicated shared genetic influences on cardiovascular and cognitive functions.
title: Heart-brain connections: phenotypic and genetic insights from 40,000 cardiac and brain magnetic resonance images

finding: The SNP rs1042725 in the HMGA2 locus was associated with type 2 diabetes and demonstrated a higher odds ratio in the top quartile of cardiovascular disease (CVD) topic weight (1.18±0.02) compared to the bottom quartile (1.00±0.02). This finding, with a significance of P=3 × 10^-7 for the top/bottom quartile test, suggested that this variant is particularly influential in individuals with cardiovascular comorbidities related to T2D.
title: Age-dependent topic modelling of comorbidities in UK Biobank identifies disease subtypes with differential genetic risk

finding: The locus rs7310615 in SH2B3 was linked to higher volume in the right optic radiation and increased volume in the left Heschl’s gyrus, emphasizing its role in the brain's language processing networks related to dyslexia.
title: Distinct impact modes of polygenic disposition to dyslexia in the adult brain

finding: The SNP rs188571756 situated at the 12q13.3 locus was also recognized as a novel risk locus for MDD and MI, highlighting its role in the shared genetic etiology of these conditions.
title: Role of Blood Lipids in the Shared Genetic Etiology Between Major Depressive Disorder and Myocardial Infarction: A Large-scale Multi-trait Association Analysis

finding: The variant rs3782449 in RBM19 was identified with a P-value of 8.90×10−6 and an OR of 0.73, suggesting a protective effect. This finding was replicated using the IIBDGC dataset.
title: Genome-wide analysis of individual coding variants and HLA-II-associated self-immunopeptidomes in ulcerative colitis

finding: The variant rs4766697 was associated with ocular manifestations in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and had a protective direction of effect, although not reaching statistical significance in the current study.
title: Genome-wide analysis of individual coding variants and HLA-II-associated self-immunopeptidomes in ulcerative colitis

finding: This missense variant located in TAS2R43 influenced UC treatment responses and was identified with significant associations (P-value=6.17×10−6, OR=1.92).
title: Genome-wide analysis of individual coding variants and HLA-II-associated self-immunopeptidomes in ulcerative colitis

finding: The SNP rs28416520 in the gene PIWIL1 exhibited a recessive effect, showing significant influence on age at natural menopause (ANM) with a very low p-value of 2×10^-14. This finding indicated that individuals with the homozygous genotype for one of the alleles experienced a notably different ANM compared to heterozygous individuals, implying a crucial genetic determinant related to reproductive longevity.
title: Genetic insights into the biological mechanisms governing human ovarian ageing

finding: The SNP rs75770066 located in the HELB gene was identified as having a heterozygous advantage effect, showing that heterozygous carriers had a higher mean age at natural menopause (95% CI: 51.37-51.58 years) compared to common homozygous (50.24-50.30 years) and rare homozygous (48.58-50.16 years) groups. This finding suggested important implications for understanding genetic factors influencing ovarian ageing.
title: Genetic insights into the biological mechanisms governing human ovarian ageing

finding: The rs10774671-G allele was associated with the OAS1-p46 protein isoform, leading to increased expression and protection from nonsense-mediated decay (NMD). It was linked to a 19Kb haplotype of 76 variants at the chr12q24.13 locus contributing to reduced risk of severe COVID-19 outcomes and enhanced SARS-CoV-2 clearance.
title: Genetic regulation of OAS1 nonsense-mediated decay underlies association with risk of severe COVID-19

finding: The missense variant rs1131454-G was identified as an exonic splicing enhancer that increased inclusion of Long exon 3 in OAS1 transcripts, leading to higher expression levels. The presence of rs1131454-G in conjunction with rs10774671-G resulted in NMD-resistance of OAS1-p46 isoforms. This variant was associated with reduced risk of severe COVID-19 due to maintained OAS1 function.
title: Genetic regulation of OAS1 nonsense-mediated decay underlies association with risk of severe COVID-19

finding: The SNP rs343086 was characterized as an intron variant in the height-associated gene HMGA2. It contributed to the leading factor for standing height, which also exhibited enrichment for musculoskeletal tissues.
title: A scalable variational approach to characterize pleiotropic components across thousands of human diseases and complex traits using GWAS summary statistics

finding: The allele of rs3184504 was associated with decreased expression of SH2B3, leading to lower risks of autoimmune diseases such as Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) and Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), while also increasing the risk for endometrial cancer.
title: Mapping inherited genetic variation with opposite effects on autoimmune disease and cancer identifies candidate drug targets associated with the anti-tumor immune response

finding: This missense variant was associated with total bilirubin levels, affecting SLCO1B1.
title: Insights from complex trait fine-mapping across diverse populations

finding: This variant was fine-mapped for fibroblastic disorders in Finnish populations.
title: Insights from complex trait fine-mapping across diverse populations

finding: Associated with PAU in the EUR analyses, this variant found in BRAP was part of the credible set with a high posterior inclusion probability.
title: Multi-ancestry study of the genetics of problematic alcohol use in >1 million individuals

finding: The study provided the first evidence that serum levels of CACNA1C were significantly elevated in subjects with bipolar disorder (BD) who carried two copies of the rs11062170 risk allele (CC). These subjects had higher CACNA1C levels in comparison to those with one (p=0.013) or no copies (p=0.009) of the allele. This association suggested a potential link between CACNA1C protein levels and the genetic predisposition to BD.
title: Differential Serum Levels of CACNA1C, Circadian Rhythm and Stress Response Molecules in Subjects with Bipolar Disorder: Associations with Genetic and Clinical Factors

finding: This SNP near the LDHB gene was found to be significantly associated with suicide attempts in individuals of European ancestries, with evidence replicating in independent samples.
title: Clinical, genomic, and neurophysiological correlates of lifetime suicide attempts among individuals with alcohol dependence

finding: This SNP, located in the ARNTL2 gene, was identified in a study focusing on individuals of African ancestries, showing an association with suicide attempts and was replicated in subsequent analyses.
title: Clinical, genomic, and neurophysiological correlates of lifetime suicide attempts among individuals with alcohol dependence

finding: The SNP variant rs35767, located in the regulatory region of the IGF1 gene, was associated with elevated circulating IGF-1 levels. The analysis indicated that possessing a single risk allele at this SNP corresponded to a 50% increase in the risk of Death Censored Graft Failure (DCGF) among kidney transplant (KTx) recipients, with an adjusted hazards ratio of 1.50 (p = 0.01). This association highlights the detrimental impact of elevated IGF-1 levels on long-term KTx outcomes, especially given that genetic variations account for a significant proportion (38%) of variance in IGF-1 levels.
title: The Growth Hormone-IGF-1 axis is a risk factor for Long-Term Kidney Allograft Failure

finding: The variant rs33990080, located within the SLC15A4 gene, was reported as a novel genetic risk variant for idiopathic gastroparesis. Carriers of this variant demonstrated a significantly higher nausea score at baseline compared to non-carriers. The association had a p-value of less than 10^-17 and an odds ratio of 1.9.
title: The role of M1 to M2 macrophage polarization in the etiology of idiopathic gastroparesis: GWAS perspective

finding: Variant rs10847696 was among the top variants identified in the GWAS analysis for idiopathic gastroparesis, with a highly significant p-value of less than 0.000004 and an odds ratio of 1.9, indicating its strong association with the condition.
title: The role of M1 to M2 macrophage polarization in the etiology of idiopathic gastroparesis: GWAS perspective

finding: This SNP reached nominal significance across all three populations (EUR, AFR, EAS) with p-values below 0.05, indicating a consistent direction of effect. It was found intronic to KCTD10, associated with neurotic disorders.
title: Genome-wide association study investigating short and long sleep duration: a cross-population meta-analysis

finding: The SNP rs2943692 located at 12:57442315 was found to be the lead variant associated with INHBC in the pQTL analysis, indicating its potential causal association with T2D.
title: Circulating proteomic profiles are associated with the onset of type 2 diabetes in a multi-ethnic Asian population – a longitudinal study

finding: Associated with SUOX, its expression was linked to the proliferation and progression of various cancers including keratinocyte cancers.
title: A multi-phenotype analysis reveals 19 novel susceptibility loci for basal cell carcinoma and 15 for squamous cell carcinoma

finding: An intronic SNP in ATXN2 linked to hypothyroidism and noted for its association with immune regulatory phenotypes and cancer susceptibility.
title: A multi-phenotype analysis reveals 19 novel susceptibility loci for basal cell carcinoma and 15 for squamous cell carcinoma

finding: Linked to LRRC43, this SNP was associated with skin allergic diseases and psoriasis.
title: A multi-phenotype analysis reveals 19 novel susceptibility loci for basal cell carcinoma and 15 for squamous cell carcinoma

finding: The rs76904798 variant was independently associated with Parkinson's disease (PD) risk with an odds ratio of 1.15 (95% CI: 1.13-1.18, P=1.52e-28). This association remained significant even after excluding carriers of relatively rare LRRK2 coding variants, indicating that it influenced PD risk separately from other coding variations such as p.G2019S.
title: LRRK2 coding variants and the risk of Parkinson’s disease

finding: The SNP rs6539267 exhibited a significant interaction with cumulative pre- and perinatal adversity, positively correlating with tic severity (F= 6.80, P= 0.001). The CC genotype in conjunction with increased pre- and perinatal adversities was linked to heightened tic severity, although these findings could not be independently replicated.
title: Investigation of gene-environment interactions in relation to tic severity

finding: The variant was reported associated with serum levels of L-lactate dehydrogenase A chain protein (LDHA).
title: Ancestrally diverse genome-wide association analysis highlights ancestry-specific differences in genetic regulation of plasma protein levels

finding: Another Finnish-enriched non-synonymous variant found in LUM was also associated with DD, having an odds ratio of 2.86.
title: A meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies in 614,243 individuals identifies 59 novel susceptibility loci underlying Dupuytren’s contracture

finding: The SNP rs4767027 was strongly associated with circulating OAS1 levels (P=6.20×10−26) in serum. This association suggests that the rs4767027 SNP likely contributes to COVID-19 outcomes, as a standard deviation increase in OAS1 correlates with reduced COVID-19 death/ventilation (OR=0.48), hospitalization (OR=0.60), and susceptibility (OR=0.81). The evidence from sensitivity analyses and the Bayesian test for colocalization suggested a shared causal signal for OAS1 levels and COVID-19 outcomes.
title: Circulating Proteins Influencing COVID-19 Susceptibility and Severity: a Mendelian Randomization Study

finding: The female-biased tag eSNP rs7294478 was located in an intron of C1RL-AS1 on chromosome 12. The differential GR-response eQTL effect was observed specifically in females on TAPBPL expression, while no such effect was noted in males. The major allele was associated with higher TAPBPL expression after dexamethasone administration in females, contrasting with the opposite effect in males. TAPBPL had been identified previously in females with significantly differentially regulated expression.
title: Autosomal sex-biased genetic regulation of the stress response

finding: Similar to rs1374204, rs7968682 was categorized as an outlier for ASD. Upon removing it from analyses, the odds ratio shifted to 1.21, indicating a potential influence on the outcomes for ASD, which further highlighted the necessity of considering outliers in genetic association studies.
title: Mendelian randomization study of birth weight and risk of psychiatric disorders later in life

finding: The SNP rs3138142 was significantly associated with PRC layer thickness, linked to RDH5 which encodes an enzyme crucial in the retinoid cycle and associated with fundus albipunctatus, a retinal dystrophy.
title: Sub-cellular level resolution of common genetic variation in the photoreceptor layer identifies continuum between rare disease and common variation

finding: The SNP rs11614913 located in MIR196A2 was positively associated with hip shape mode 9 (HSM9), which indicates a wider femoral neck and larger femoral head (P = 2.76×10^−10). It was novel for this study and additionally protective against hip fracture.
title: Genome-wide association study of DXA-derived hip morphology identifies associations with 4 loci in Chinese populations

finding: The finding related to rs10774671 indicated that it harbored a mutation from the Neanderthal genome leading to a splice variant. This splice variant was associated with protection from severe COVID-19. The RNA-seq analysis revealed that this haplotype was present in 83% of the control population, 86% of the unvaccinated Omicron population, and 85% of the vaccinated Omicron population, while showing 96% prevalence in the Alpha population.
title: Prior vaccination enables a more robust immune response to Omicron infection

finding: The rs11049367 variant in the 12p11.22 locus was associated with functional connectivity traits in the frontoparietal and default mode networks, especially between the right p9-46v and right TE1m areas, indicating its relevance to neural connectivity.
title: Genetic influences on the intrinsic and extrinsic functional organizations of the cerebral cortex

finding: Identified as a novel trans-pQTL for lymphotoxin alpha (LTA), where the multiple sclerosis risk allele was tied to increased LTA levels and decreased LTBR expression.
title: Mapping pQTLs of circulating inflammatory proteins identifies drivers of immune-related disease risk and novel therapeutic targets

finding: Linked as an independent disease signal near TNFRSF1A, emphasizing its role in multiple sclerosis susceptibility.
title: Mapping pQTLs of circulating inflammatory proteins identifies drivers of immune-related disease risk and novel therapeutic targets

finding: SNP rs11066132 was identified as one of the most pleiotropic variants, being associated with 23 traits, indicating its significant impact on multiple phenotypes.
title: Genome-wide study on 72,298 Korean individuals in Korean biobank data for 76 traits identifies hundreds of novel loci

finding: Similar to rs11066132, SNP rs116873087 was also an intron variant in NAA25 and linked to 23 traits, showcasing its extensive pleiotropic effects.
title: Genome-wide study on 72,298 Korean individuals in Korean biobank data for 76 traits identifies hundreds of novel loci

finding: The SNP rs12310399 located in the FGD6 gene was identified as a new risk locus for ruptured intracranial aneurysms (rIA). It reached genome-wide significance (p=3.19×10^-10, OR=1.16) and was found to cause decreased FGD6 gene expression in arterial tissue, highlighting its role in rIA pathogenesis. This finding was notable as it had not been implicated in prior GWAS of rIA.
title: Integrative genomics analysis implicates decreased FGD6 expression underlying risk of intracranial aneurysm rupture

finding: The SNP rs3184504 was part of the sparse PRS model for celiac disease, which contained 428 variants including imputed HLA allelotypes and variants near the MHC region on chromosome 6. In this context, the rs3184504 variant in the SH2B3 gene showed a log odds ratio (log(OR)) of 0.15 in the multivariate PRS model, indicating a potential association with the risk of developing celiac disease, as SH2B3 is involved in crucial cellular signaling processes.
title: Significant Sparse Polygenic Risk Scores across 813 traits in UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs3184504 was reported as a significant finding related to Celiac disease in the context of a sparse PRS model that included 428 variants. The analysis indicated that this missense variant in the SH2B3 gene had a log(OR) of 0.15 in the multivariate PRS model, suggesting its positive association with the risk of developing Celiac disease.
title: Significant Sparse Polygenic Risk Scores across 813 traits in UK Biobank

finding: The genetic variant rs747096195 (R101G) was found to cause reduced efficiency in acetaldehyde metabolism, leading to acetaldehyde accumulation after alcohol consumption. In trials, participants carrying this mutation demonstrated a 2-fold increase in acetaldehyde levels compared to wild-type ALDH2, and their alcohol challenge outcomes showed longer metabolization times, corroborating in vitro findings.
title: Phenotyping aldehyde metabolism in humans uncovers novel genetic mutations in aldehyde dehydrogenase 2

finding: The genetic variant rs190764869 (R114W) similarly resulted in an impaired capability to metabolize acetaldehyde, being characterized as having reduced enzymatic activity. Participants with this mutation also exhibited significant acetaldehyde accumulation during alcohol challenges, validating the reduced metabolism findings observed in recombinant enzyme studies.
title: Phenotyping aldehyde metabolism in humans uncovers novel genetic mutations in aldehyde dehydrogenase 2

finding: The SNP rs3764002 was identified as having potentially deleterious effects, indicating its relevance to pain intensity in the context of chronic pain.
title: The genetic architecture of pain intensity in a sample of 598,339 U.S. veterans

finding: The study indicated that the rs10774671 haplotype was present in 83% of the control population (TCT cohort) and showed high prevalence in both the unvaccinated (86%) and vaccinated (85%) Omicron-infected individuals. The finding was significant as the rs10774671 variant was associated with increased OAS1 expression, particularly in unvaccinated Omicron patients and those infected with the Alpha variant, suggesting a link between this SNP and a protective response against severe COVID-19.
title: Differences in transcriptional response underlie why prior vaccination exceeds prior infection in eliciting robust immune responses in Omicron infected outpatients

finding: The locus rs597808 was found to be a common risk locus between systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and premature coronary atherosclerosis, achieving genome-wide significance (P<5 × 10−8). This SNP was associated with decreased HDL and LDL cholesterol levels, indicating its role in dyslipidemia within SLE patients, which could contribute to the acceleration of coronary atherosclerosis.
title: Association between Systemic Lupus Erythematosus and Coronary Heart Disease: a retrospective case-control analysis and Mendelian Randomization Study

finding: The variant rs3782860 at locus 12p13.33 was associated with chronotype and retinal thickness.
title: The role of sleep in the human brain and body: insights from multi-organ imaging genetics

finding: The variant rs2080402 at locus 12p13.33 was linked to retinal thickness and its associations with chronotype.
title: The role of sleep in the human brain and body: insights from multi-organ imaging genetics

finding: The SLCO1B1 rs4149032 polymorphism was found to be highly prevalent in South Africans and was associated with reduced rifampicin concentrations, which had significant implications for dosing in tuberculous meningitis treatments.
title: Plasma pharmacokinetics of high dose oral versus intravenous rifampicin in patients with tuberculous meningitis: a randomized controlled trial

finding: This SNP, mapped to SUDS3, was significantly associated with PSA levels, adding to the genetic insights into prostate cancer.
title: Incorporating Genetic Determinants of Prostate-Specific Antigen Levels Improves Prostate Cancer Screening

finding: The SNP rs10128882 was identified in colocalization analyses affecting LIN7A and ACSS3 expression specifically within the Mexican ancestry population. The T2D risk allele was linked to decreased expression levels of both genes, with differential LD observed across populations.
title: Multi-omics characterization of type 2 diabetes associated genetic variation

finding: SNP rs11114650 demonstrated a colocalization effect with rs10128882, with it showing high allele frequency in African populations compared to European populations. It was associated with decreased LIN7A and ACSS3 expression levels.
title: Multi-omics characterization of type 2 diabetes associated genetic variation

finding: The SNP rs3184504 was part of the sparse PRS model for celiac disease, an autoimmune disorder related to gluten consumption. It was identified as a missense variant located on chromosome 12, specifically in the gene SH2B3, which encodes an adaptor protein involved in cellular signaling. The log(OR) for this variant in the multivariate PRS model was reported as 0.15, indicating its contribution to the disease risk.
title: Significant Sparse Polygenic Risk Scores across 428 traits in UK Biobank

finding: The variant rs138740163 (MAF=1.0%) increased the risk for 'Mittelschmerz' (ovulation pain) by more than 5-fold among women, with an odds ratio (OR) of 6.00.
title: Genetic architecture and shared mechanisms of common ‘neglected’ diseases

finding: This SNP showed significance with a p-value of 5.05×10⁻²¹ and was linked to the metal transporter ZIP8, contributing to the understanding of iron transport mechanisms.
title: Hemochromatosis Neural Archetype Reveals Iron Disruption in Motor Circuits

finding: The SNP rs1468603 was analyzed for its effects on splicing events related to the PLEKHG6 gene. The T allele of this SNP was predicted to activate an exonic cryptic acceptor, enhancing the inclusion of an in-frame 45 bp deletion in PLEKHG6, indicating its potential causal role in colorectal cancer (CRC).
title: Integrating multi-tissue expression and splicing data to prioritise anatomical subsite- and sex-specific colorectal cancer susceptibility genes with therapeutic potential

finding: The rs4760682 variant in the PFKM gene was linked with glycolysis and was involved in the regulation of plasma pyruvate levels, indirectly supporting the viability of red blood cells.
title: Mendelian randomisation with proxy exposures: challenges and opportunities

finding: This eQTL variant near the HAL gene was positively associated with skin cancer and negatively with vitamin D levels, indicating its multifaceted relationships with metabolic pathways and disease risk.
title: Mendelian randomisation with proxy exposures: challenges and opportunities

finding: The HAL variant rs61937878 was linked to both plasma histidine and vitamin D levels, emphasizing its probable role in vitamin D metabolism as well as its pleiotropic effects on other metabolites.
title: Mendelian randomisation with proxy exposures: challenges and opportunities

finding: Associated with histidine levels, the rs117991621 variant in the HAL gene corroborated findings of histidine's weak relationships with vitamin D levels, suggesting it does not influence vitamin D levels directly.
title: Mendelian randomisation with proxy exposures: challenges and opportunities

finding: The eSNP rs7294478 was located in an intron of C1RL-AS1 on chromosome 12. It showed a significant effect exclusively in females on TAPBPL expression, which is positioned over 700 kb downstream and was identified as a significant differential response gene in females (FDR = 0.00068), whereas no effect was observed in males.
title: Sex differences in the genetic regulation of the blood transcriptome response to glucocorticoid receptor activation

finding: For the tag eSNP rs934891, it was observed that upon GR-stimulation with dexamethasone, gene expression levels for the gene DUSP6 showed significant variation across genotypes in females, with an FDR of 0.049.
title: Sex differences in the genetic regulation of the blood transcriptome response to glucocorticoid receptor activation

finding: The SNP rs56368105 was positively associated with hip shape modes HSM4, HSM9, and HSM10, indicating a narrower femoral neck and larger femoral head (β 0.06, P 1.60×10<sup>-18</sup> for HSM4; β 0.08, P 4.73×10<sup>-31</sup> for HSM9; β 0.05, P 1.18×10<sup>-14</sup> for HSM10). Additionally, it was protective for hip fracture (β -0.08, P 1.38×10<sup>-7</sup>), suggesting a genetic influence in hip shape that could affect fracture risk.
title: Hip shape shows a causal effect on hip fracture but not hip osteoarthritis: findings from a GWAS meta-analysis and causal analyses

finding: The SNP rs736825 showed positive associations with HSM4, HSM9, and HSM10, correlating with a narrower femoral neck and larger femoral head (β 0.06, P 1.60×10<sup>-18</sup> for HSM4; β 0.08, P 4.73×10<sup>-31</sup> for HSM9; β 0.05, P 1.18×10<sup>-14</sup> for HSM10). It was also found to be protective against hip fracture (β -0.08, P 8.87×10<sup>-8</sup>), contributing to understanding variations in hip shape relevant for fracture susceptibility.
title: Hip shape shows a causal effect on hip fracture but not hip osteoarthritis: findings from a GWAS meta-analysis and causal analyses

finding: The SNP rs11614913 was positively associated with hip shape modes HSM4, HSM9, and HSM10, specifically indicating a narrower femoral neck and larger femoral head (β 0.06, P 1.60×10<sup>-18</sup> for HSM4; β 0.08, P 4.73×10<sup>-31</sup> for HSM9; β 0.05, P 1.18×10<sup>-14</sup> for HSM10). Unlike rs56368105 and rs736825, rs11614913 was associated with increased risk for hip fracture (β 0.08, P 4.73×10<sup>-31</sup>), illustrating its different role in fracture risk relative to other variants.
title: Hip shape shows a causal effect on hip fracture but not hip osteoarthritis: findings from a GWAS meta-analysis and causal analyses

finding: The SNP rs10850579 was found to significantly influence methylation at the site cg14016568, showing a beta value of -1.20, a standard error of 0.05, and a p-value of 1.10×10^-28. This finding further elucidated the epigenetic factors that could underlie the pathology of osteoarthritis.
title: Epigenomic profiling of the infrapatellar fat pad in osteoarthritis

finding: The SNP rs1006737, located within intron 3 of the schizophrenia (SZ) risk gene CACNA1C, was linked to variable mRNA expression levels. This suggests that the SNP may influence gene expression related to schizophrenia.
title: Long-read sequencing reveals the RNA isoform repertoire of neuropsychiatric risk genes in human brain

finding: The rs3741596 missense variant (S218G) in the ORAI1 gene was associated with an increased risk of hospital-diagnosed peripheral vascular disease (PVD), generalised atherosclerosis, acute ischaemic heart disease, and atrioventricular and left bundle-branch block among White British UK Biobank participants. Specifically, carriers of this variant demonstrated a 1.7-fold risk (OR=1.7, 95% CI=1.1-2.7, P=0.012) for PVD hospitalization. Additional associations included significantly higher circulating platelet counts and a reduction in total triglyceride levels. Functional analysis indicated that the S218G variant enhanced SOCE (store-operated calcium entry) in HEK293 cells, suggesting an overall gain-of-function effect related to vascular pathologies.
title: A rare ORAI1 missense variant associates with risk of vascular diseases in White British adults

finding: The SNP rs377424471 at the MLXIP locus was significantly associated with early onset IS, showing an odds ratio of 0.90 (95% CI: 0.86-0.94). It was noted that this SNP had not been previously associated with stroke and showed no evidence of association with late onset stroke.
title: Genetic Contributions to Early and Late Onset Ischemic Stroke

finding: The SNP rs2270788 in the ABCB9 gene was associated with both the risk and tumor size of uterine leiomyomas in African American participants. ABCB9 is involved in the transport process associated with the development and progression of various malignant tumors, and its expression was found to be downregulated in women with high levels of progesterone serum compared to those with lower levels. This regulation is significant since progesterone is a known promoter of leiomyoma development.
title: Exploring potential causal genes for uterine leiomyomas: A summary data-based Mendelian randomization and FUMA analysis

finding: The rs11049367 variant located in the 12p11.22 region was associated with functional connectivity traits in the frontoparietal and default mode networks, especially showing connectivity effects between specific areas in these networks during fMRI tasks.
title: Genetic influences on the intrinsic and extrinsic functional organizations of the cerebral cortex

finding: The SNP rs12308154 (LGR5) was identified to have a strong head-specific effect on bone mineral density (BMD) with a p-value of 1.5e-9. It was shown to influence bone formation and remodeling through regulation of the WNT signaling pathway.
title: Valid inference for machine learning-assisted GWAS

finding: The rs5030654 variant in PAH associated with phenylketonuria was found to be among the known high-frequency variants overrepresented in the healthy donor group.
title: Expanding the Russian allele frequency reference via cross-laboratory data integration: insights from 7,452 exome samples

finding: The SNP rs1050288 was also among the causal variants linked to cardiovascular traits in Europeans, adding to the body of evidence for genetic determinants of cardiovascular health.
title: Distinct Genetic Loci and Variations in Blood Pressure and Pulse Rate in Europeans and Africans from the UK Biobank

finding: The rs768676371 variant was reported as a missense variant in the D-amino acid oxidase (DAO) gene, causing a glycine-to-valine substitution at amino acid 131 (DAO<sup>G131V</sup>). This variant was found to co-segregate with bipolar disorder in a studied family, and there was evidence of its rarity and association with the disorder.
title: A rare variant in D-amino acid oxidase implicates NMDA receptor signaling and cerebellar gene networks in risk for bipolar disorder

finding: Associated with SHS-PC3, rs11494758 was identified as linked to a distinct sleep health trait, further implicating the KLRG1 gene in sleep-related mechanisms.
title: Genome-wide association analysis of composite sleep health scores in 413,904 individuals

finding: This SNP showed significant association with cardiovascular traits specifically in the EUR population (p=2.9×10^-55), indicating its relevance within the population-specific genetic frameworks.
title: Multitrait Genome-Wide Analysis in the UK Biobank Reveals Novel and Distinct Variants Influencing Cardiovascular Traits in Africans and Europeans

finding: The sentinel SNP rs4149056 located in the SLCO1B1 locus was significantly associated with decreased serum levels of glycochenodeoxycholic acid (GDCA). Its strong association (p=1.14 × 10^-16) was consistent across 4 out of 5 populations studied, with the effect allele T correlating with decreased GDCA levels. This SNP was also a missense variant (p.Val174Ala) impacting the gene's function, previously linked to various metabolite levels including bilirubin and triglycerides.
title: Genome-wide association study reveals loci with sex-specific effects on plasma bile acids

finding: The rs73079476 variant located in high linkage disequilibrium with rs4149056 was significantly associated with GDCA in males (beta = -0.51, p-value = 2.28 × 10^-13), while in females, the same variant showed consistent directionality but did not reach significance (beta = -0.31, p-value = 9.86 × 10^-7), indicating a stronger genetic effect of the SLCO1B1 locus on bile acid levels in males.
title: Genome-wide association study reveals loci with sex-specific effects on plasma bile acids

finding: SNP rs12304921, with a p-value of 5.05x10^-21, was also identified in the study. It is associated with another metal transporter gene, DMT1, which is involved in gut iron absorption and previously linked to anemia. Its significance in the context of iron homeostasis makes it relevant to both iron overload conditions and possibly movement disorders.
title: Neural Archetypes Learnt from Hemochromatosis Reveals Iron Dysregulation in Motor Circuits

finding: At the FAIM2 locus, rs7132908 showed colocalization with the expression of AQP6 in thyroid tissue and ASIC1 in prostate tissue across many cell types.
title: 3D genomic features across >50 diverse cell types reveal insights into the genomic architecture of childhood obesity

finding: The SNP rs111486601 near the LHX5-AS1 gene was identified as a novel GWS variant associated with Alzheimer's disease with P=1.1×10^-8, showing a protective effect (OR=0.63). This association was primarily driven by Hispanic individuals.
title: Multi-ancestry genome-wide meta-analysis of 56,241 individuals identifies LRRC4C, LHX5-AS1 and nominates ancestry-specific loci PTPRK, GRB14, and KIAA0825 as novel risk loci for Alzheimer’s disease: the Alzheimer’s Disease Genetics Consortium

finding: SNP rs11065577 emerged as one of seven novel loci unique to the latent MDD-CVD association study, showing suggestive associations (p < .05) with metabolic traits, thereby linking it to underlying risk factors shared between MDD and CVD.
title: Distinct biological signature and modifiable risk factors underly the comorbidity between major depressive disorder and cardiovascular disease

finding: The rs7132908 SNP at the FAIM2 locus was associated with both AQP6 and ASIC1 gene expressions, showing significant colocalization across multiple metabolic and neural cell types related to obesity.
title: 3D genomic features across >50 diverse cell types reveal insights into the genomic architecture of childhood obesity

finding: The variant rs35350651 was linked to seven autoimmune traits, demonstrating its significant role in influencing multiple autoimmune conditions.
title: 3D chromatin-based variant-to-gene maps across 57 human cell types reveal the cellular and genetic architecture of autoimmune disease susceptibility

finding: The variant rs653178 was implicated in seven autoimmune traits, highlighting its potential relevance across a variety of autoimmune diseases.
title: 3D chromatin-based variant-to-gene maps across 57 human cell types reveal the cellular and genetic architecture of autoimmune disease susceptibility

finding: The study identified the allele C at rs695871 as consistently present in SCA2 carriers, and a rare haplotype G-C-G-A-T was identified, containing a G allele at rs695871. This contradicted previous findings that linked SCA2 expansions universally to the C allele at this SNP.
title: Spinocerebellar ataxia type 2 has multiple ancestral origins

finding: This SNP was included in the haplotype analysis and was associated with expanded ATXN2 alleles. It was highlighted among the significant genetic markers in the study, although specific allele frequencies related to SCA2 were not detailed in the context provided.
title: Spinocerebellar ataxia type 2 has multiple ancestral origins

finding: It was identified as one of the SNPs in the haplotype analysis. Its inclusion was crucial in evaluating the whole genetic variance in SCA2 among the studied families, indicating a role in the disorder's origins.
title: Spinocerebellar ataxia type 2 has multiple ancestral origins

finding: Selected for its disequilibrium binding with the CAG region, this SNP contributed to the overall understanding of genetic variations associated with SCA2 in the populations studied.
title: Spinocerebellar ataxia type 2 has multiple ancestral origins

finding: This SNP also had previous associations with AD only in Europeans, being merely below the genome-wide significance threshold in the European analysis.
title: European and multi-ancestry genome-wide association meta-analysis of atopic dermatitis highlights importance of systemic immune regulation

finding: Lead SNP rs9651873 was associated with PTSD and displayed a high CADD score, which indicated its potential impact on gene expression and neuronal functions within the context of PTSD and its neurobiological underpinnings.
title: The genetic relationships between post-traumatic stress disorder and its corresponding neural circuit structures

finding: The SNP rs1860356 was associated with angina, reporting an OR<sub>IVW</sub> of 1.005, 95% CI of 1.003 to 1.007, and a significant p-value of <0.001, highlighting its contribution to angina risk.
title: Causality of Genetically Determined Monounsaturated Fatty Acids on Risk of Cardiovascular Disease: A Mendelian Randomization Study

finding: This SNP was associated with FAIM2 across 25 cell types, and its influence extended to metabolic and neural cell systems, implicating it in the broader context of obesity pathophysiology.
title: 3D genomic features across >50 diverse cell types reveal insights into the genomic architecture of childhood obesity

finding: The variant rs4963772 was found to be significantly associated with multiple cardiac diseases and various MRI-derived cardiac traits. It was identified within the SOX5 locus and had a minimum P value of 3.55 × 10⁻¹⁴, indicating its importance in cardiac health. Additionally, this variant was significant in previous genome-wide association studies (GWAS) related to blood pressure and atrial fibrillation.
title: Unsupervised cardiac MRI phenotyping with 3D diffusion autoencoders reveals novel genetic insights

finding: This missense variant was identified within the high-confidence effector gene WSCD2. It was associated with BMI, type 2 diabetes, and neuropsychiatric disorders. The alteration in protein function it induces was predicted to be damaging, linking it to both diseases.
title: Insights into the comorbidity between type 2 diabetes and osteoarthritis

finding: This SNP reached genome-wide significance in the latest meta-analysis of knee osteoarthritis and was included in the credible set for colocalization of type 2 diabetes and knee osteoarthritis at the WSCD2 locus, indicating a substantial genetic correlation.
title: Insights into the comorbidity between type 2 diabetes and osteoarthritis

finding: The SNP rs11057830 associated with SCARB1 was identified as significant for hypercholesterolemia using the CC-liability approach. This was consistent with findings from other GWAS, supporting its relevance in lipid-related disorders.
title: Genetic association studies using disease liabilities from deep neural networks

finding: This intergenic variant achieved significance in both the cardiometabolic interaction and joint tests (p = 1.37×10^-8 and 4.85×10^-8, respectively). It served as an eQTL for METTL25, implying a potential regulatory role in immune responses that could influence COVID-19 severity.
title: Gene-environment interaction analysis incorporating sex, cardiometabolic diseases, and multiple deprivation index reveals novel genetic associations with COVID-19 severity

finding: The likely pathogenic variant p.V377I in the MVK gene, linked to hyper-IgD syndrome (OMIM: 260920), was significantly enriched in the Qatar Arab subpopulation with an AF of 0.8%, while being absent in the 1000 genomes and showing very low frequencies (approximately 0.15%) in Esp6500, gnomAD V2, and gnomAD V3.
title: Genetic landscape of rare autoinflammatory disease variants in Qatar and Middle Eastern populations through the integration of whole-genome and exome datasets

finding: The intronic SNP rs74651308 within SLCO1A2 reached significance at p = 2.86 × 10^-7, reflecting a beta of 0.51.
title: Whole-Genome Sequencing Analysis Reveals New Susceptibility Loci and Structural Variants Associated with Progressive Supranuclear Palsy

finding: The SNP rs11568563 was linked to a significant association with PSP, reported with a p-value of 1.45 × 10^-6.
title: Whole-Genome Sequencing Analysis Reveals New Susceptibility Loci and Structural Variants Associated with Progressive Supranuclear Palsy

finding: The reported SNP rs147124286 in the SP1 region was associated with a p-value of 4.39 × 10^-7.
title: Whole-Genome Sequencing Analysis Reveals New Susceptibility Loci and Structural Variants Associated with Progressive Supranuclear Palsy

finding: The lead SNP rs12817984 was associated with PSP at p = 8.91 × 10^-8.
title: Whole-Genome Sequencing Analysis Reveals New Susceptibility Loci and Structural Variants Associated with Progressive Supranuclear Palsy

finding: The SNP rs11050663 was evaluated within the context of chemoreradiotherapy strategies for unresectable locally advanced pancreatic cancer, discussing its therapeutic implications.
title: Graph Attention Networks for Drug Combination Discovery: Targeting Pancreatic Cancer Genes with RAIN Protocol

finding: The OGFOD2/CCDC62 rs11060180 G-carriers exhibited significantly higher UPDRS-III scores compared to AA carriers, indicating its association with motor symptoms in Parkinson's disease.
title: Parkinson’s disease-associated genetic variants synergistically shape brain networks

finding: The LRRK2 rs76904798 was significantly associated with verbal memory function in Parkinson's disease patients, indicating its involvement in cognitive performance.
title: Parkinson’s disease-associated genetic variants synergistically shape brain networks

finding: The minor A allele of rs138380449 was associated with 1.7 standard deviations (SD) higher levels of injury/inflammation (SE=0.44, p=0.0001). This result was part of the analysis showing that rare variants in the IFFO1 gene contribute to neuronal injury and inflammation, potentially heightening the risk for dementia.
title: Rare variants in IFFO1, DTNB and NLRC3 associate with Alzheimer’s disease CSF profile of neuronal injury and inflammation

finding: The minor A allele of rs139792267 was associated with 1.3 SD higher levels of injury/inflammation (SE=0.45, p=0.0037). Like rs138380449, this SNP is located in the IFFO1 gene which was linked to processes relevant to Alzheimer's disease pathology.
title: Rare variants in IFFO1, DTNB and NLRC3 associate with Alzheimer’s disease CSF profile of neuronal injury and inflammation

finding: The T allele of rs17836273, which causes an A98T substitution in the EF-hand domain of the Rab46 protein, showed a significant association with COVID-19 fatality. The odds ratio (OR) reported was 1.43 (p = 0.012), indicating that individuals with this variant had an increased risk of mortality due to COVID-19. This amino acid change occurred in a highly conserved region essential for calcium binding, suggesting its potential impact on protein function.
title: EFCAB4B (CRACR2A) genetic variants associated with COVID-19 fatality

finding: The T allele of rs36030417 resulted in an H212Q substitution in the coiled-coil domain of the Rab46 protein, which was also significantly associated with COVID-19 fatality, with an OR of 1.39 (p = 0.013). The finding underscored the variant's association with severe outcomes in COVID-19, given its role in protein-protein interactions critical for Rab46 functionality.
title: EFCAB4B (CRACR2A) genetic variants associated with COVID-19 fatality

finding: The C allele of rs9788233 led to an R7G substitution at the N-terminus of Rab46 protein, significantly correlated with COVID-19 mortality, evidenced by an OR of 1.51 (p = 0.004). This mutation occurred in a structurally undefined region, and its conservation across species suggested potential biological relevance in the context of severe COVID-19 outcomes.
title: EFCAB4B (CRACR2A) genetic variants associated with COVID-19 fatality

finding: The SNP rs10843036 was specifically associated with pregnancy zone protein (PZP) in females, indicating its relevance in female reproductive health.
